title: RV visualization
text:
! pip install scipy
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import binom

# parameters for the binomial distribution
n = 10
p = 0.5

# generate the values for x
x = np.arange(0, n+1)

# calculate the PMF
pmf = binom.pmf(x, n, p)

# create the plot
plt.bar(x, pmf)
plt.xlabel('Number of Successes')
plt.ylabel('Probability')
plt.title('PMF of a Binomial Distribution (n=10, p=0.5)')
plt.show()




Figure 1: Probability Mass Function (PMF) of a discrete random variable with binomial distribution





! pip install pandas
! pip install altair
! pip install seaborn
! pip install matplotlib
import pandas as pd
import altair as alt
import seaborn as sns
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt


penguins = pd.read_csv("https://pos.it/palmer-penguins-github-csv")



Code
penguins.groupby("species").size().reset_index(name = "count")









species
count




0
Adelie
152


1
Chinstrap
68


2
Gentoo
124








colors = ["#FF8C00", "#A020F0", "#008B8B"]
sns.set_palette(colors, n_colors = 3)


penguins["bill_ratio"] = (
   penguins["bill_length_mm"] / penguins["bill_depth_mm"] 
)
sns.displot(penguins, 
            x = "bill_ratio", 
            hue = "species", 
            kind = "kde", fill = True, aspect = 2, height = 3)
plt.show()




Figure 2: ?(caption)





sns.displot(penguins, 
            x = "bill_depth_mm", 
            hue = "species", 
            kind = "kde", fill = True, 
            aspect = 2, height = 3)
plt.show()
sns.displot(penguins, 
            x = "bill_length_mm", 
            hue = "species", 
            kind = "kde", fill = True, 
            aspect = 2, height = 3)
plt.show()







(a) Gentoo penguins tend to have thinner bills,







(b) and Adelie penguins tend to have shorter bills.




Figure 3: Marginal distributions of bill dimensions




scale = alt.Scale(domain = ['Adelie', 'Chinstrap', 'Gentoo'],
                  range = colors)


alt.Chart(penguins).mark_circle(size=60).encode(
    alt.X('bill_length_mm',
        scale=alt.Scale(zero=False)
    ),
    alt.Y('bill_depth_mm',
        scale=alt.Scale(zero=False)
    ),
    color = alt.Color('species', scale = scale),
    tooltip=['species', 'sex', 'island']
)

title: Random Variable Visualization
text:
! pip install scipy

Requirement already satisfied: scipy in /Users/mdshahedulhaque/miniconda3/envs/jupyter_venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages (1.11.4)
Requirement already satisfied: numpy<1.28.0,>=1.21.6 in /Users/mdshahedulhaque/miniconda3/envs/jupyter_venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages (from scipy) (1.26.2)



import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import binom
# parameters for the binomial distribution
n = 10
p = 0.5

# generate the values for x
x = np.arange(0, n+1)

# calculate the PMF
pmf = binom.pmf(x, n, p)


# create the plot
plt.bar(x, pmf)
plt.xlabel('Number of Successes')
plt.ylabel('Probability')
plt.title('PMF of a Binomial Distribution (n=10, p=0.5)')
plt.show()




Figure 1: Probability Mass Function (PMF) of a discrete random variable with binomial distribution

title: Random Variable Visualization
text:
! pip install scipy

Requirement already satisfied: scipy in /Users/mdshahedulhaque/miniconda3/envs/jupyter_venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages (1.11.4)
Requirement already satisfied: numpy<1.28.0,>=1.21.6 in /Users/mdshahedulhaque/miniconda3/envs/jupyter_venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages (from scipy) (1.26.2)



import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import binom
# parameters for the binomial distribution
n = 10
p = 0.5

# generate the values for x
x = np.arange(0, n+1)

# calculate the PMF
pmf = binom.pmf(x, n, p)


# create the plot
plt.bar(x, pmf)
plt.xlabel('Number of Successes')
plt.ylabel('Probability')
plt.title('PMF of a Binomial Distribution (n=10, p=0.5)')
plt.show()




Figure 1: Probability Mass Function (PMF) of a discrete random variable with binomial distribution

title: Random Variable Visualization
text:
PDF

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm

# parameters for the normal distribution
mu = 0
sigma = 1

# generate the values for x
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)
# calculate the PDF
pdf = norm.pdf(x, mu, sigma)


# create the plot
plt.plot(x, pdf)
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('Probability Density')
plt.title('PDF of a Normal Distribution (mu=0, sigma=1)')
plt.show()




Figure 2: Probability Density Function (PDF) of a continous random variable with normal distribution

title: Random Variable Visualization
text:
CDF

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm

# parameters for the normal distribution
mu = 0
sigma = 1

# generate the values for x
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)
# calculate the PDF
cdf = norm.cdf(x, mu, sigma)


# create the plot
plt.plot(x, cdf)
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('Cumulative Probability')
plt.title('CDF of a Normal Distribution (mu=0, sigma=1)')
plt.show()




Figure 3: Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of a continous random variable with normal distribution

title: Welcome To My Blog
text: This is my first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

title: Random Variable
text:
A random variable (stochastic variable) is a real valued function from the domain of the sample space of a defined experiment. Generally, a random variable is denoted by capital letter (usually \(X\) ) where small letter (\(x\)) denotes the observed value. For example, \(X\) be the measurement of number of heads observed in an experiment of tossing two coins. Here, the sample space \(S\) is:
\[ S = {(H, H), (H, T), (T, H), (T, T) } \]
This 4 possible outcomes of this experiment constitute the domain of $X$. For each outcome, the random variable is calculates in this way:
\[  X(H, H) = 2  \]$$ X(H, T) = 1 $$
\[  X(T, H) = 1 \] $$ X(T, T) = 0 $$


In broader way, there are two categories of random variable:

Discrete Random Variable: Range of the observable value is a finite set. For instance, in the previous two coins tossing \(X\) is a discrete random variable with observable values \(\{0, 1, 2\}\) .
Continuous Random Variable: Range of the observable value has some interval, bounded or unbounded. For instance, weight of different people in a class.






The probability mass function (PMF) a discrete random variable is the likelihood that the variable takes on a given value. Mathematically,
\[  f(x) = P(X = x) \]
which follows the following properties:
\[  f(x) \geq 0 \mbox{ for any $x$ \(\epsilon\)
$S$ } \]

\[  \sum_{x \epsilon S} f(x) = 1  \]
Code snippet for calculating PMF of a discrete random variable which follows binomial distribution:


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import binom
# parameters for the binomial distribution
n = 10
p = 0.5

# generate the values for x
x = np.arange(0, n+1)

# calculate the PMF
pmf = binom.pmf(x, n, p)

Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library
Then we can plot the PMF of that variable better visualization






Figure 1: Probability Mass Function (PMF) of a discrete random variable with binomial distribution




Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library



The probability density function (PDF) of a continuous random variable is the likelihood that the variable lies on a given range. Mathematically,
\[ \int_{a}^{b} f(x)dx = P(a< X <b) \mbox{ for any $a, b$ \(\epsilon\) $S$ satisfying a < b }\]
which follows the following properties:
\[  f(x) \geq 0 \mbox{ for any $x$ \(\epsilon\)
$S$ } \]
\[  \int_{x \epsilon S} f(x)dx = 1  \]
Code snippet for calculating PDF of a continuous random variable which follows normal distribution:


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm

# parameters for the normal distribution
mu = 0
sigma = 1

# generate the values for x
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)
# calculate the PDF
pdf = norm.pdf(x, mu, sigma)

Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library
Then we can plot the PDF of that variable better visualization






Figure 2: Probability Density Function (PDF) of a continous random variable with normal distribution




Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library



The cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a random variable is the likelihood that the variable is bounded within a given value. Mathematically,
\[ F(x) = \sum_{z \epsilon S, z \leq x } f(z) \mbox{ for discrete random variables }\]
\[ F(x) = \int_{- \infty}^{x} f(z)dz  \mbox{ for continuous random variables }\]
Furthermore,
\[  P(a< X \leq b) = F(b) - F(a)  \]
Code snippet for calculating CDF of a continuous random variable which follows normal distribution:


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm

# parameters for the normal distribution
mu = 0
sigma = 1

# generate the values for x
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)
# calculate the PDF
cdf = norm.cdf(x, mu, sigma)

Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library
Then we can plot the CDF of that variable better visualization






Figure 3: Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of a continous random variable with normal distribution




Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library

title: Random Variable
text:
In broader way, there are two categories of random variable:

Discrete Random Variable: Range of the observable value is a finite set. For instance, in the previous two coins tossing \(X\) is a discrete random variable with observable values \(\{0, 1, 2\}\) .
Continuous Random Variable: Range of the observable value has some interval, bounded or unbounded. For instance, weight of different people in a class.






The probability mass function (PMF) a discrete random variable is the likelihood that the variable takes on a given value. Mathematically,
\[  f(x) = P(X = x) \]
which follows the following properties:
\[  f(x) \geq 0 \mbox{ for any $x$ \(\epsilon\)
$S$ } \]

\[  \sum_{x \epsilon S} f(x) = 1  \]
Code snippet for calculating PMF of a discrete random variable which follows binomial distribution:


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import binom
# parameters for the binomial distribution
n = 10
p = 0.5

# generate the values for x
x = np.arange(0, n+1)

# calculate the PMF
pmf = binom.pmf(x, n, p)

Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library
Then we can plot the PMF of that variable better visualization






Figure 1: Probability Mass Function (PMF) of a discrete random variable with binomial distribution




Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library



The probability density function (PDF) of a continuous random variable is the likelihood that the variable lies on a given range. Mathematically,
\[ \int_{a}^{b} f(x)dx = P(a< X <b) \mbox{ for any $a, b$ \(\epsilon\) $S$ satisfying a < b }\]
which follows the following properties:
\[  f(x) \geq 0 \mbox{ for any $x$ \(\epsilon\)
$S$ } \]
\[  \int_{x \epsilon S} f(x)dx = 1  \]
Code snippet for calculating PDF of a continuous random variable which follows normal distribution:


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm

# parameters for the normal distribution
mu = 0
sigma = 1

# generate the values for x
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)
# calculate the PDF
pdf = norm.pdf(x, mu, sigma)

Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library
Then we can plot the PDF of that variable better visualization






Figure 2: Probability Density Function (PDF) of a continous random variable with normal distribution




Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library



The cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a random variable is the likelihood that the variable is bounded within a given value. Mathematically,
\[ F(x) = \sum_{z \epsilon S, z \leq x } f(z) \mbox{ for discrete random variables }\]
\[ F(x) = \int_{- \infty}^{x} f(z)dz  \mbox{ for continuous random variables }\]
Furthermore,
\[  P(a< X \leq b) = F(b) - F(a)  \]
Code snippet for calculating CDF of a continuous random variable which follows normal distribution:


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm

# parameters for the normal distribution
mu = 0
sigma = 1

# generate the values for x
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)
# calculate the PDF
cdf = norm.cdf(x, mu, sigma)

Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library
Then we can plot the CDF of that variable better visualization






Figure 3: Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of a continous random variable with normal distribution




Source: Random Variable with Scipy Library

title: Dummy
text:
A random variable (stochastic variable) is a real valued function from the domain of the sample space of a defined experiment. Generally, a random variable is denoted by capital letter (usually \(X\) ) where small letter (\(x\)) denotes the observed value. For example, \(X\) be the measurement of number of heads observed in an experiment of tossing two coins. Here, the sample space \(S\) is:
\[ S = {(H, H), (H, T), (T, H), (T, T) } \]
This 4 possible outcomes of this experiment constitute the domain of $X$. For each outcome, the random variable is calculates in this way:
\[  X(H, H) = 2  \]$$ X(H, T) = 1 $$
\[  X(T, H) = 1 \] $$ X(T, T) = 0 $$


In broader way, there are two categories of random variable:

Discrete Random Variable: Range of the observable value is a finite set. For instance, in the previous two coins tossing \(X\) is a discrete random variable with observable values \(\{0, 1, 2\}\) .
Continuous Random Variable: Range of the observable value has some interval, bounded or unbounded. For instance, weight of different people in a class.






The probability mass function (PMF) a discrete random variable is the likelihood that the variable takes on a given value. Mathematically,
\[  f(x) = P(X = x) \]
which follows the following properties:
\[  f(x) \geq 0 \mbox{ for any $x$ \(\epsilon\)
$S$ } \]

\[  \sum_{x \epsilon S} f(x) = 1  \]



The probability density function (PDF) a continuous random variable is the likelihood that the variable lies on a given range. Mathematically,
\[ \int_{a}^{b} f(x)dx = P(a< X <b) \mbox{ for any $a, b$ \(\epsilon\) $S$ satisfying a < b }\]
which follows the following properties:
\[  f(x) \geq 0 \mbox{ for any $x$ \(\epsilon\)
$S$ } \]
\[  \int_{x \epsilon S} f(x)dx = 1  \]



The cumulative distribution function (PDF) a random variable is the likelihood that the variable is bounded within a given value. Mathematically,
\[ F(x) = \sum_{z \epsilon S, z \leq x } f(z) \mbox{ for discrete random variables }\]
\[ F(x) = \int_{- \infty}^{x} f(z)dz  \mbox{ for continuous random variables }\]
Furthermore,
\[  P(a< X \leq b) = F(b) - F(a)  \]




For separating the actual environment in my local machine, I created a virtual environment and utilized the req.txt file to install the necessary library and packages.











Figure 1: ?(caption)




Source: penguins.ipynb
You may include the code from a cell along with the output by using the echo=true option. For example, to include the code and the plot from the cell labelled species-counts the embed would be:



Code
penguins.groupby("species").size().reset_index(name = "count")
